statement:
In the following, let $X$ be a topological space.

Suppose $Y\subseteq X$ is equipped with the subspace topology, and
$A\subseteq Y$. Then $A$ is in $Y$ if and only if $A=Y\cap J$ for some
closed set $J\subseteq X$.

If $A$ is closed in $Y$, then $Y\setminus A$ is in $Y$, and by the
definition of the subspace topology, $Y\setminus A = Y\cap U$ for some
open $U\subseteq X$. Using , we obtain $$\begin{aligned}
  A &=& Y\setminus (Y\setminus A) \\
    &=& Y\setminus(Y\cap U) \\
    &=& Y\setminus U \\
    &=& Y\cap U^\complement.\end{aligned}$$ On the other hand, if
$A=Y\cap J$ for some closed $J\subseteq X$, then
$Y\setminus A = Y\setminus(Y\cap J) = Y\cap J^\complement$, and so
$Y\setminus A$ is open in $Y$, and therefore $A$ is closed in $Y$.

Suppose $X$ is a topological space, $C\subseteq X$ is a closed set
equipped with the subspace topology, and $A\subseteq C$ is closed in
$C$. Then $A$ is closed in $X$.

This follows from the previous theorem: since $A$ is closed in $C$, we
have $A = C\cap J$ for some closed set $J\subseteq X$, and $A$ is closed
in $X$.
